bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, December 23, 1952

div1.p: Hench suggests that Smith invite Nogueira to be the Cuban correspondent for the “Journal of the American Medical Association.” He praises Nogueira for fulfilling his promises in a timely fashion, knowing everyone in Cuban political life, and for his knowledge of medicine.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, December 23, 1952
div1.opener:
December 23, 1952
REF: AS:P
Dr. Austin Smith, Editor
Journal of the American Medical Association
535 North Dearborn Street
Chicago 10, Illinois
My dear Doctor Smith:
div1.p:
In regard to your letter of December 16, if you can wait until the end of
January, I will send you a write-up of the Camp Lazear dedication which you
can rewrite as you choose. Would you like to have one or two photographs,
glossy prints for reduplication?

With regard to your desire to get a correspondent in Havana, I have given
the matter some thought and would suggest the name of Dr. Pedro Nogueira,
Marti 219, Marianao, Havana. Let me tell you a little about Doctor Nogueira.

I have visited Havana many times in the last 15 years and have become, as
you doubtless are, quite familiar with the intense interest which their
medical men have in politics. Gran was a physician of course and Dr. Domingo
Ramos has been in and out of government as Minister of Defense, Minister of
of Sanitation, etc. As a result, the doctors, like the rest of the Cubans,
are strongly factional and when one political party goes in the medical
politicians and the other parth often make no bones about their animosity
towards each other. I say this because I do not think you will find any,
or many, Cuban physicians who would be aggressive enough to send you a regular
letter who were not involved in politics in some way and therefore who were
not unfriendly with at least certain other Cuban physicians and factions.

In connection with my Camp Lazear venture, I have had many contacts with many
Cuban physicians and politicians, high and low. Of the old school, Dr. Ramos
was the best and most reliable but he is now rather old, in semi-retirement,
etc. By far the most aggressive and consistently productive Cuban physician
I have ever met is Dr. Pedro Nogueira, a young dynamo if there ever was one.
Through the eight or ten years of my association with him, I have been simply
amazed at his energy and through those many years he has kept faith with me
100 per cent, fulfilling every one of innumerable promises he has made to me;
most of the time immediately, only occasionally delayed.

He has two or three jobs. His chief and official one is head of the Sanitary
Unit of Marianao. This appears to be a branch of the Finlay Institute and
I think he is more or less the head of the Public Health Department of the
center of Havana called Quemados de Marianao. He is also the head physician
of one of the largest breweries, the one that runs “Tropical Gardens.” He is
also physician to a rat extermination company and, in addition, runs a private
practice. Despite his interest in industrial medicine, he seems to be greatly
interested in internal medicine and seems to be pretty well up on such matters
Dr. Austin Smith
- 2 -
December 23, 1952
as cortisone, etc. He is well known to Doctor Fishbein and other Americans
who have visited there and indeed he may be well known to you. The one draw-
back is that he writes English poorly but if you decided upon him and per-
mitted him to write the letter in Spanish, then your own translators could
work on it. Whether he would be willing or able to add this job to his other
burdens without at least nominal financial remuneration, I do not know. But
of one thing I am certain. If he took it on, you would probably get more
cooperation and prompt service from him than from any other Cuban I ever met.

He seems to know everybody in Cuban political life. I have walked with him
into the mayor's office, into the offices of the various ministers and Pedro
waves a greeting to this and that person, kids the doorman and we just walk
right in, into the inner sanctum anywhere. However, unfortunately, he is
not in the best graces with the present administration. He is known to be
an anti-Batista man and although he and Saladriguez, the present Minister
of Health, cooperated well enough as far as the Camp Lazear ceremonies were
concerned, there were some behind-the-scenes political shadows. He was
friendly to both the Gran and the Prio administrations. He is a young man,
I would say in his mid-40's.

If you do not wish to consider him, I think Tom Spies could give you some
excellent suggestions as of course Tom goes to Havana about every six weeks
in connection with his research and clinical work at the University of Havana.
Two other names come to my mind: Dr. Jose Centurion, one of the better known
internists who is about 50 years old, and Dr. Juan Portuondo, one of the
younger internists.

Regardless of politics, Nogueira seems to be in the good graces of the of-
ficers of the Academy of Science. He is quite friendly with the old president,
Doctor Presno and on December 3, Finlay's birthday, it was Doctor Nogueira
who gave the main oration of the evening at the Academy of Science when the
Finlay Condecoracions were handed out.

Thank you for inquiring about the cost of the wreath. It cost me $15. It
was a beautiful wreath of tremendous size. I was lucky to get them all from
the same florist. When she was introduced to me she recognized my name because
“her mother's eyesight was saved by cortisone recently”; therefore she gave
me some tremendous wreaths I am sure at cost or less.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
